newsitem.title: USA: Medtronic Q1 bolstered by ICD sales growth.
newsitem.headline: Medtronic Q1 bolstered by ICD sales growth.

text.p: Medtronic Inc, the largest U.S. manufacturer of medical devices, on Tuesday reported solid profit gains for its quarter ended Aug. 1 on the back of strong growth in sales of implantable defibrillators, or ICDs.
Topping the First Call consensus estimate by a penny, Medtronic posted first-quarter earnings of $0.63 per share, up from $0.53 per share in the same period a year ago.
Net sales rose to $646.3 million on the quarter from $600.8 million, the company reported.

"Heavy expenditures on research and development over a number of years have leveraged our core competencies into new therapeutic devices that are now winning market acceptance," said chairman and chief executive William George.

Performance in the company's key pacing business benefitted from a 37.2-percent unit-sales increase in sales of ICDs, or small electronic devices implanted in the body and wired to the heart to keep it from beating too fast.
Unit volumes of pacemakers -- similar to ICDs but designed to keep the heart from beating too slowly -- grew in the mid-single-digit range, Medtronic said.
Sales in the company's vascular business posted a quarterly growth rate in the high teens, as sales of coronary stents grew nearly 50 percent on a constant-currency basis.
Neurological sales rose more than 30 percent on a constant currency basis, the company said.
Cardiac surgery revenues rose modestly, highlighted by strong sales of bioprosthetic heart valves and surgical cannulae, Medtronic said.
